''Stability Constants'', Chemical Society, London, 1958.</ref> }} }} '''Isobutyric acid''', also known as '''2-methylpropanoic acid''', is a [[carboxylic acid]] with structural formula ([[carbon|C]][[hydrogen|H]]<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>-CH-[[carboxyl group|COOH]]. It is found in the free state in carobs (''[[Ceratonia siliqua]]''), in [[vanilla]] and in the root of ''[[Arnica]] dulcis'', and as an ethyl [[ester]] in croton oil. Isobutyric acid is an [[isomer]] of ''n''-[[butyric acid]]; they have the same chemical formula [[carbon|C]]<sub>4</sub>[[hydrogen|H]]<sub>8</sub> [[oxygen|O]]<sub>2</sub> but a different structure. == Production == Isobutyric acid may be artificially prepared by the [[hydrolysis]] of [[isobutyronitrile]] with [[alkali]]s, by the [[oxidation]] of [[isobutanol]] with [[potassium dichromate]] and [[sulfuric acid]],<ref>{{cite journal| author=I. Pierre and E. Puchot | title = New Studies on Valerianic Acid and its Preparation on a Large Scale |journal=Ann. de chim. et de phys. |year=1873 |volume=28 |pages=366}}</ref> or by the action of [[sodium amalgam]] on [[methacrylic acid]]. It is a liquid of somewhat unpleasant smell, boiling at 155 °C. Its specific gravity is 0.9697 (0 °C). Heated with [[chromic acid]] solution to 140 °C, it gives [[carbon dioxide]] and [[acetone]]. Alkaline [[potassium permanganate]] oxidizes it to α-hydroxyisobutyric acid, (CH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>-C(OH)-COOH. Its [[salt]]s are more soluble in water than those of [[butyric acid]]. === Biological production === Isobutyric acid can also be manufactured commercially using engineered bacteria using a sugar feedstock.<ref>{{cite web|title=Biological pathways to produce methacrylate|url=http://www.license.umn.edu/Products/Biological-Pathways-Produce-Isobutyric-Acid-Using-Renewable-Resources__20110077.aspx}}</ref> Isobutyric acid is a retained trivial name under the IUPAC rules.<ref name=IUPAC2993>{{BlueBook1993|rec=R-9.1|url=http://www.acdlabs.com/iupac/nomenclature/93/r93_705.htm}}</ref> == References == {{reflist}} {{1911}} [[Category:Carboxylic acids]] [[Category:Chemical compounds found in Vanilla]]
